sect1.title: Modem Lights Applet
sect1.para:
Modem Lights Applet monitors your modem while it is working. To add this applet to a Panel, right-click on the panel and choose
Add to panel Internet Modem Lights

sect2.title: Usage
sect2.para: This applet can be used to tell if your modem is working, and to track its behavior and performance. It can also be configured to call a separate script or program to have your modem connect and disconnect when you click on the button with the single green light.

Right-clicking on the applet brings up a menu containing the following items:
Preferences— brings up the preferences dialog
Help — brings up this document.
About — shows basic information about the Modem Lights Applet, including the applet's version and author's name.

sect2.title: Customization
sect2.para: You can customize Modem Lights Applet by right-clicking on it and choosing Preferences. This will open the Modem Lights Preferences dialog which allows you to change various settings.

The preferences are:
Connect command: and Disconnect command: — To use Modem Lights Applet to initiate a connection, place the name of the startup command in the Connect command text box, and the disconnect command in the box beneath it labeled Disconnect command. When you click on the single button on the applet, it will connect or disconnect your modem.
Confirm connection — Display a dialog box confirming your connection.
Updates per second — Set the update rate of Modem Lights Applet's display.
Show connect time and throughput — add two text windows to the applet showing the time you have been connected at the data transfer rate. This is a good way to monitor your modem's performance.
Modem Lights Applet's Color preferences window allows you to select the colors to be used when displaying the applet.

The preferences are:
Receive data — specifies the colors to be used when the applet displays data being received. You can select both foreground and background colors.
Send data — specifies the colors to be used when the applet displays data being sent. You can select both foreground and background colors.
Connection status — specifies the colors relating to the wether the connection is connected, not connected, or awaiting connection. By selecting Blink, you can enable blink for the connection status.
Text — specifies the colors used to display the text and text fields. You can select foreground, background, and outline colors.
Modem Lights Applet's Advanced preferences window allows you to control advanced features of the applet.

The preferences are:
Modem lock file: — specifies the file created by the computer when the modem is working, allowing other programs to know it is in operation. /var/lock/LCK..modem, the default setting, is the most common, if your computer uses a symbolic link from /dev/modem to the actual modem device. Check with your system administrator to see if a different device name and therefore lock file is in use. Modem Lights Applet needs this information to find and monitor your modem.
You can determine the correct lock file name by establishing a PPP connection and then changing into the /var/lock directory. There should now be a new lock file. This is most likely the one you need for the applet.
Verify owner of lock file — verify that the lockfile really belongs to the currently running PPP daemon and is not left over from an older one. This is checked by default and shouldn't be changed.
Device — Device, typically ppp0 on a Linux machine, is the name of the network interface being used by the modem. If ppp0 is not correct for your machine, check your system documentation for the correct designation.
Other possible network interface names commonly used include ippp0 for Linux ISDN; isp0 for NetBSD ISDN and ipdptp0 for Solaris PPP.
Use ISDN — If you use an ISDN modem, check the Use ISDN checkbox. Modem Lights Applet will then ignore all the settings above related to standard modems.
